Nice stuff Jim. another case in study would be the treatment of the 
Sukashi Horse theme we see in Akasaka by Tadashige, Ito/Bushu ( iron and 
Shakudo and Shoami. I would not be surprised to see the same treatment 
done in Tosa Myochin works. I think if a smith liked a theme, or maybe 
even mores the case , 'I saw your Akasaka tsuba while you were visiting 
my house and had one made by my local guy' then the copying of themes in 
tsuba could be rife.

My late Akasaka ( we think ) example.
http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/akasaka-horse.jpg

Rich



Jim Gilbert wrote:

> David,
> The same motif often appears through groups spread around the 
> country.  Since we were talking Akasaka, many of the later Akasaka 
> guards (made in Edo) were lifted directly from work originating in 
> Higo (Kyushu).  Of course there are also general motifs that persist 
> across long spans of time and space.  That's culture.
>
> There are extant pattern books for later iroe shiiremono tsuba.  I 
> don't think that I've seen one for sukashi guards, but they might have 
> existed.  But, think about our own culture... there are many common 
> and persistent motifs that aren't set forth in a pattern book.
>
> The doubled elements at 12:00 and 6:00 are myoga - ginger shoots.  At 
> 3:00 and 9:00 are of course tea whisks.  On the diagonals are folding 
> fans and linking them all are birds.  The inside of the rim is a very 
> loose kiri.  The groups of three dots that you mention as problematic 
> are a standard part of the depiction of myoga in that period.
>
> Jim
>
